section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter contains procedures for administrative hearings in contested cases conducted under the Maryland Vehicle Law. These procedures are in accordance with the Maryland Administrative Procedure Act, State Government Article, §10-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland, and the Maryland Vehicle Law, Transportation Article, §12-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Administration" means the Motor Vehicle Administration.
"Administrative law judge" means a person authorized to conduct hearings in contested cases under State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 16, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Administrator" means the Motor Vehicle Administrator.
"Contested case" means a proceeding so defined under the Maryland Administrative Procedure Act.

"Licensee" is one whose legal rights, duties, statutory entitlements, or privileges may be affected by the outcome of a contested case, including an applicant for a license issued under the Maryland Vehicle Law.
"Party" includes a licensee, the State, and a secured party under a hearing held pursuant to Transportation Article, Title 13, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
In a contested case, all parties shall be afforded an opportunity for hearing after reasonable notice.
The notice shall include:
The date, time, and place of the hearing;
The legal authority and jurisdiction of the Administration to hear the matter,
The specific section of each statute and regulation, including a procedural regulation, that is pertinent;
The facts in sufficient detail to enable a party to prepare his case;
The nature of the proposed action that the Administration is to consider;
The right of a party to the hearing to be represented by counsel; and

If a licensee is a party to the hearing, the right of the Administration, on failure of the licensee to appear, to order a suspension of the licensee's license or privilege until the licensee appears for a hearing.

Except as provided in §§D and E of this regulation, the notice shall be given at least 10 days before the date of the hearing. A hearing shall be scheduled within 30 days of the date a party requests a hearing. Notice shall be sent to the party as provided in Transportation Article, §12-114, and State Government Article, §10-208, Annotated Code of Maryland.

If the Administration has immediately suspended a licensee's driving privilege after determining that there is a likelihood of substantial and immediate danger and harm to the licensee or others, the Administration shall provide a hearing within 7 days of a party's request.

A hearing shall be conducted at the location indicated in the notice, except that if the Administration determines that it is necessary to take testimony from a law enforcement officer, the hearing may be convened or reconvened at the Administration's hearing location most convenient to the assigned duty station of the law enforcement officer.

Postponements may be granted only for good cause by the Administrator, or the Administrator's designee. In addition, in cases in which an administrative law judge is the trier of fact, the chief administrative law judge, the Manager of the Division of Administrative Adjudication, or their appointees may grant a postponement for good cause. However, once an administrative law judge is assigned a case, the administrative law judge may, for good cause, grant a postponement.

Except for good cause, a request for a postponement of a hearing may not be considered unless a written request for it has been received by the Administration not less than 5 days before the scheduled date of the hearing. The written request shall set forth the reasons for the request and shall list at least three dates within the 60-day period following the day of the previously scheduled hearing on which the party and, if applicable, counsel will be available for a hearing.
A postponement request shall constitute a waiver of the licensee's right to a hearing or a decision within the time periods established by law.

section.heading: Request for Subpoenas or Summonses. — Repealed

para.text: Pursuant to State Government Article, §10-205, and Transportation Article, §12-104, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Administrator delegates authority to hear contested administrative hearings and issue final orders to certain administrative law judges appointed by the Office of Administrative Hearings.

Unless specifically provided elsewhere in Transportation Article, Annotated Code of Maryland, or other Motor Vehicle regulations, administrative hearing procedures shall be in accordance with the procedures in COMAR 28.02.01.
Each hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the rules of evidence in State Government Article, §§10-213 and 10-214, and Transportation Article, §12-207, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Notwithstanding the fact that evidence may have been seized or obtained in violation of a licensee's Fourth Amendment constitutional rights, the evidence is admissible unless the:
Police officer, in obtaining or seizing the evidence, acted in bad faith and not as a reasonable officer should act in similar circumstances; or
Evidence is otherwise inadmissible under this regulation.

Except as provided in §B of this regulation, an individual who is not authorized to participate in the decision-making process of a contested case may not communicate ex parte with the Administrator, the administrative law judge, other trier of fact, or any individual who is involved in the decision-making process with regard to any issue of law or fact in the contested case.

The Administrator, administrative law judge, other trier of fact, or any individual who is involved in the decision-making process may communicate with the Administration's staff or with counsel for the Administration as long as those individuals did not participate in the investigation or prosecution of the contested case.

section.heading: Failure to Appear.
section.text: If a licensee who has been given notice of the hearing fails to appear for the hearing, the Administration may:

para.text: Suspend the applicable privilege pending the licensee's appearance at a hearing on a date set by the Administration; or

Upon good cause shown to the satisfaction of the Administration as to why the licensee could not appear at the originally scheduled hearing, terminate any suspension imposed under this regulation, and send notice to the licensee of the newly scheduled hearing date.

section.heading: Cost of Transcript.
section.text: Testimony presented at any hearing may be transcribed. However, a party requesting a transcript prepared by the Administration shall pay for its cost. A party requesting a transcript prepared by a private stenographic service shall pay whatever cost is assessed by the private service.

para.text: Subject to the court's assessment of costs at the conclusion of a case, a party filing an appeal from a decision of the Administration shall pay the expense of the transcription of the testimony. However, the Administration shall bear the expense of the transcription if the court in which the appeal was filed has waived prepayment of the filing fees pursuant to Maryland Rule 1-325.
The Administration shall notify the Office of Administrative Hearings to provide the Administration with the audiotape of the testimony at the hearing.

Unless a stenographer designated by the Administration has already recorded this testimony, the Administration shall deliver the audiotape to the private stenographic service designated by the Administration and shall notify the private stenographic service to deliver, to the administrative law judge who presided over the hearing:
The original transcript and four copies; and
The invoice made payable by the Motor Vehicle Administration.

The Administration, after verifying the accuracy of the transcript through the Office of Administrative Hearings, and after the administrative law judge has made whatever corrections that are considered necessary, shall obtain the original transcript and three copies from the Office of Administrative Hearings.

Unless the appellant is exempt under §A of this regulation, the Administration may not file the original transcript and record with the court until the appellant reimburses the Administration for the cost of:
The original transcript; and
Certified copies of the exhibits to be filed with the court.
The appellant shall:
Comply with the time constraints imposed by Maryland Rule 7-206; and
Request from the court any extensions of time for preparing the record and transcript to allow the Administration to file the record and transcript with the court in a timely fashion.

section.heading: Stay of Enforcement.
section.text: A party may request a stay of enforcement of the Administration's decision if an appeal has been filed. A request for a stay shall be in writing and shall include a photocopy of the order for appeal filed with the circuit court. Except for hearings conducted pursuant to Transportation Article, §16-205.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Administration shall grant a stay of the Administration's decision or order for not more than 120 days, unless it appears to the Administration that substantial and immediate harm could result to the licensee or others if the license or privilege is continued pending appeal.
